JUDGES: Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä;Sverre Erik Jebens;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is an NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in ORG . He is currently working as legal officer at ORG . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
In DATE the applicant was appointed as a prosecutor at ORG ( “ DPO ” ) . From DATE to DATE the applicant worked as a prosecutor at ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) .

In DATE the Prosecutor General ( “ the ORG ” ) proposed that the applicant be transferred to another DPO , as a result of which he would be demoted and his earnings would decrease . The applicant contested the proposal on the ground that there was no reason for his transfer and demotion .

On DATE ORG endorsed the ORG ’s proposal . By virtue of a presidential decree of DATE , the applicant ’s transfer took effect . On DATE the applicant took up his functions as prosecutor at the Pogradec DPO . His basic remuneration was halved .
On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional appeal with ORG against the presidential decree .
On DATE ORG declared his complaint inadmissible for non - exhaustion of remedies as provided for under LAW ( f ) of LAW .

On DATE the applicant challenged his transfer before ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) . He argued that the transfer and demotion were in breach of ORG and adversely affected his career , income and related expenses .

On DATE ORG decided to transfer the case to ORG ( “ the Court of Appeal ” ) , on the grounds that it lacked jurisdiction . It reasoned that the applicant ’s transfer was akin to a disciplinary measure , for which ORG had initial jurisdiction pursuant to section CARDINAL of ORG .

On an unspecified date , while the proceedings were pending before ORG , the applicant made a claim for compensation for loss of earnings as a result of the transfer . In his final submissions to ORG , the applicant argued that the said court was competent to examine issues relating to the transfer of prosecutors . He contended that his transfer had been contrary to the domestic law in so far as he had not given his opinion , the transfer had not been on the same hierarchical level and the subsequent demotion had not been temporary . He maintained that he had suffered a loss of earnings as a result of the transfer .

On DATE ORG found in the applicant ’s favour and quashed the presidential decree . It held that the applicant ’s transfer had affected his employment relationship and resulted in the change of his job and a decrease in remuneration . The court interpreted section CARDINAL of ORG to mean that the applicant ’s consent was required for the transfer , in the absence of which the procedure was not in compliance with the law . There was no mention of the applicant ’s claim for compensation for loss of earnings .
On DATE the ORG ’s office appealed to ORG .

In an effort to harmonise the judicial practice inter alia on the legal nature of the presidential decree and its amenability to judicial review , on DATE the President of ORG decided that the case should be examined by ORG ( Kolegjet e Bashkuara ) .

On DATE ORG , by CARDINAL votes to CARDINAL , quashed ORG judgment , holding that a presidential decree in relation to the appointment , transfer or dismissal of a prosecutor was not subject to judicial review , owing to the special employment relationship that existed between the ORG and such officials . ORG decided to discontinue the case .

On DATE the applicant appealed to ORG . He argued that the decision of DATE had breached his right of access to a court . He further submitted that the presidential decree ordering his transfer was an administrative act , which was subject to judicial review .

On DATE the ORG quashed ORG decision . Relying on its decision no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG found that the presidential decree concerning the appointment and dismissal of a prosecutor was an administrative act which should be amenable to judicial review . Since ORG had not examined the merits of the ORG ’s office appeal , the case was remitted for a determination of the merits .

On DATE ORG held a hearing . The applicant argued that his transfer was not justified . He was of the view that the term “ opinion ” in section CARDINAL of ORG should be interpreted as “ consent ” . He further contended that the transfer , which resulted in his demotion and a decrease in his remuneration , was unlawful .

The ORG ’s ORG argued that the transfer was grounded on the organisational needs of the prosecutor ’s office . It was not essential to have the consent of the prosecutor to his transfer . Other prosecutors had also been transferred against their wishes .

On DATE ORG , by CARDINAL votes to CARDINAL , quashed ORG judgment and dismissed the applicant ’s claims . It found that the applicant ’s transfer had occurred “ out of necessity and in the interest of work ” in accordance with section CARDINAL of ORG . It further held that the applicant ’s consent to his transfer was not required by law . The law only stipulated that the applicant ’s opinion be sought before his transfer .

ORG recognised the applicant ’s right to seek compensation for loss of earnings and other benefits . However , since the applicant ’s claim was directed at the unlawfulness of the presidential decree and since ORG had not examined his compensation claim , ORG decided that it could not examine that claim of its own motion . It ruled however that the applicant could file afresh a claim for compensation for loss of earnings . To date , it does not appear that the applicant has lodged a new claim for compensation with ORG .
Of the CARDINAL judges of ORG who voted against the case on DATE , DATE had been members of the bench which , on DATE , had dismissed the case .

On DATE the applicant appealed to ORG and challenged the decision of DATE . He claimed that his case had not been heard by “ a tribunal established by law ” in rehearing proceedings . Since the decision of ORG did not aim at harmonising and unifying judicial practice , the applicant argued that his case should have been heard by a ORG instead of ORG in rehearing proceedings . He also complained that , despite his request for compensation for loss of earnings , ORG refusal to award him compensation for damage as a result of the transfer and demotion was against its case - law ( see the “ Relevant domestic law and practice ” section below ) . In his view , this amounted to a lack of impartiality .

On DATE ORG , by means of a reasoned decision , rejected the applicant ’s appeal . It found that there had been no breach of the applicant ’s right of access to a court on account of the courts’ failure to examine his additional claim for damages . ORG decided that his claim for compensation submitted to ORG did not meet the requirements of a proper civil action in so far as the claim had not been quantified . The lower courts were therefore not obliged to examine the request . Moreover , ORG had informed the applicant of his right to lodge a new civil claim for damages .

ORG further found that the examination by ORG had been by a tribunal established by law . It found that the applicant ’s claim regarding the lack of impartiality of ORG Joint Benches in the rehearing proceedings was ill - founded .

In an article entitled “ The judicial review of the lawfulness of administrative acts ” , published in a law journal in DATE , the then President of ORG concluded that presidential decrees concerning the appointment , dismissal and ranking of military officers , prosecutors or ambassadors could not be subject to judicial review .

Under LAW ( f ) ORG decides on “ final complaints by individuals alleging a violation of their constitutional rights to a fair hearing , after all legal remedies for the protection of those rights have been exhausted . ”
LAW stipulates that ORG sits in ORG to examine cases that would harmonise or amend judicial practice .
Article PERSON provides that ORG ( “ the ORG ” - Prokuroria ) is a centralised institution .

ORG is composed of CARDINAL judges ( section CARDINAL ) . It examines cases in ORG ( section CARDINAL ) . It also sits in ORG in order to , inter alia , harmonise and amend judicial practice ( section CARDINAL ) . A request to sit in ORG is made by CARDINAL of the benches , the President of ORG or ORG ( section CARDINAL ) . The quorum for the composition of ORG is CARDINAL of all the judges . A decision is taken by a simple majority of ORG ( section CARDINAL ) .

Civil proceedings start on the strength of a civil claim ( LAW . A civil claim should contain the name of the court it is addressed to , the personal details and residence of the claimant , the object of the claim , description of facts , circumstances , documents and other evidentiary materials , the claimant ’s request and its value ( LAW ) .

ORG ( “ GP ” ) is the highest authority of the ORG ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . The structure of the ORG is made up of CARDINAL layers : the district ORG prosecutors , the courts of appeal prosecutors and ORG prosecutors , whose duties are exercised by the prosecutors attached to the ORG ( sections CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) .

District courts’ prosecutors are appointed by a decree of the President of the Republic , on the proposal of the ORG , after having had the opinion of ORG ( section CARDINAL ) . Before taking up their duties , prosecutors take an oath ( section CARDINAL ) .

According to the DATE LAW , the promotion or transfer of a prosecutor could occur only out of necessity and in the interest of work . It was finalised by a presidential decree , on the proposal of the ORG , after having heard the prosecutor ’s opinion ( section CARDINAL ) .

ORG is responsible for the appointment and appraisal of prosecutors . It also examines disciplinary breaches as a result of which it adopts advisory opinions ( sections DATE ) . Disciplinary measures may be appealed against to ORG ( section CARDINAL ) .

The case concerned the impossibility of having access to a court against a presidential decree which ordered a prosecutor ’s dismissal , as provided by LAW . In its decision no . CARDINAL of DATE ( CARDINAL ) ORG declared section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of ORG unconstitutional as it was against LAW . It thus opened the way for a prosecutor to challenge a presidential decree ordering his dismissal before a court .

The case concerned the unjust dismissal of a police officer and his right to compensation for damage . ORG ruled that a police officer who was unjustly dismissed from work was entitled to compensation for loss of earnings . Such an action did not need to be explicitly sought . It sufficed that a police officer challenged the unjust termination of his employment for the court to ( automatically ) examine the consequences that resulted from such a termination , that is , compensation for damage . The burden of proof was on the appellant in quantifying the damage .
